is of key importance for the performance of high efficiency industrial solar cells. The surface to volume ratio is increasing due to the cost- driven reduction of the solar cell thickness, which makes surface passivation a decisive factor for the final solar cell efficiency. Hydrogenated amorphous silicon nitride
is routinely applied in solar cell production as an antireflection coating on the front side and provides good surface passivation of low resistivity
- Si. However, the surface passivation of
- type emitters) is rather poor. When
is applied on the back of a
- type solar cell the high positive built- in charge induces a parasitic junction, limiting the solar cell efficiency. Thermally grown oxide is the state- of- the- art surface passivation layer for
- Si of arbitrary doping level and is used in the record- efficiency passivated emitter and rear localy- diffused (PERL)
- Si solar cell. The surface passivation of the asgrown thermal oxide is moderate, but is significantly improved by a subsequent annealing in a forming gas

). The best results are obtained by the so- called alneal scheme, where a sacrificial layer of Al is evaporated on the film prior to annealing. The oxidation of the Al film during the annealing releases atomic hydrogen that strongly reduces the number of interface defect states. However, the high processing temperatures

and elaborate processing necessary to obtain such a high quality thermal oxide are not always desirable. Therefore considerable effort is put in the development of low temperature surface passivation schemes that do not show the limitations of thermal oxide and
. Materials such as amorphous silicon carbide
have recently demonstrated a good level of surface passivation on both

- Si. However, both materials have significant absorption in the visible part of the solar spectrum. These films are also thermally unstable; hence, only steps with a low thermal budget can be used after deposition of these films.
Another interesting option is the use of the high bandgap dielectric
as a surface passivation layer. With a refractive index of
and no significant absorption in the
visible part of the solar spectrum,
is well suited to improve the optical quality at the front or the back of the solar cell. Hezel and Jaeger already demonstrated that
grown by the pyrolysis of aluminium- tri- isopropoxide can show a reasonable level of surface passivation. More recently, Agostinelli et al. have shown that
films grown by thermal atomic layer deposition provide a good level of surface passivation on
In this letter we will show that ultrathin films of
exhibit a similar level of surface passivation as alnealed thermal silicon oxide on both

- type silicon. These films were prepared by plasma- assisted atomic layer deposition (PA- ALD) allowing monolayer growth control of high quality thin films, while the plasma step enables the use of relatively short purging times and low deposition temperatures.
were grown in a homebuilt PA- ALD reactor at a substrate temperature of
. The films were prepared by alternating trimethylaluminium exposure and a remote
plasma with a total cycle time of
. The film growth was monitored by means of in situ spectroscopic ellipsometry
range) and revealed a growth rate in the

range per cycle. The atomic composition of the films was determined by means of Rutherford backscattering (RBS) and elastic recoil detection (ERD). The films were oxygen rich (Al:O = 2:3.14), and a small amount of hydrogen
) was detected in the films. The carbon content was below the detection limit of RBS
). The surface passivation was tested by depositing identical
films on both sides of low resistivity
- Si substrates. The substrates received a standard RCA clean with a final HF dip prior to deposition to remove the native oxide. After deposition, the lifetime samples were annealed in a
in a rapid thermal annealing furnace. The effective lifetime

was measured using a lifetime tester (Sinton WCT- 100) in both the quasi- steady- state and transient mode. The level of surface passivation is quantified by the effective surface recombination velocity. Assuming an infinite bulk lifetime, the upper limit of the effective surface recombination velocity

The postdeposition annealing was essential for a good level of surface passivation; however, from RBS/ERD no
significant changes could be detected in the atomic composition of the annealed
films. From high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR- TEM) it was found that both the as- deposited and annealed
films are amorphous in composition, as shown in Fig. 3 for the annealed film. An interfacial oxide layer of
prior to anneal) is present between the
as a result of the deposition process, possibly from the exposure of the substrate to the
plasma in the first ALD cycles. In a separate experiment it was verified that the oxide layer formed during the
plasma exposure in itself does not yield any surface passivation, also not after annealing.

The effective lifetimes measured for a
film in this study are significantly higher compared to the results reported for substrates passivated by
films grown by thermal ALD. The results are comparable to the best results obtained for alnealed thermal
:H and approach the results obtained for
- Si:H. It should be noted that the reported literature values were obtained for films with thicknesses in the range of
and that the level of surface passivation of
:H is reported to deteriorate for films with thicknesses below 40 and
, respectively. On the other hand, the effective lifetimes for
film are comparable to the best results obtained for alnealed thermal
- Si:H films and significantly higher than reported for
All lifetime curves in Figs. 1 and 2 show the expected decrease in effective lifetime at higher injection levels due to Auger recombination. For the
- type wafer in Fig. 1 passivated with a
, the effective lifetime shows the typical injection level dependence also reported for
:H, or thermal oxide, probably caused by Shockley- Read- Hall (SRH) recombination in the bulk or at the surface through a midgap defect. Remarkably, the lifetime curve for the
film is constant for lower injection level. For the
, the effective lifetime slightly decreases for lower injection level comparable to results obtained for
3.5 This decrease can again be attributed to SRH recombination in the bulk or at the surface.
The excellent surface passivation by the
film is mainly determined by the field effect passivation due to a large
built- in negative charge as indicated by
measurements. This negative built- in charge for
was also reported by Hezel and Jaeger and Agostinelli et al. The negative charge in

is suggested to be present at the unique tetrahedrally coordinated Al site present at the interface that has a net negative charge, in contrast to the octahedrally coordination site where Al has a charge of
17 For the commonly used thermal oxide and
positive built- in charges in the range of
the sign of the built- in charge is reported to depend on the wafer doping type.45 A negative built- in charge is especially beneficial for passivation of highly doped
The fact that the high level of surface passivation could only be obtained by a postdeposition annealing of the
) could be caused by a local reconstruction of the
at the interface, consequently increasing the negative built- in charge. In addition, hydrogen from the
bulk could diffuse and provide chemical passivation at the
interface, thereby reducing defect related recombination. A factor of 10 reduction of the interface defect density was reported for a metal- insulator- semiconductor structure with
as the insulator after a 15 min annealing at
In conclusion, we have shown that excellent surface passivation, similar to alnealed thermal oxide, can be obtained on
films prepared by the PA- ALD technique. An ultrathin film of

Si. By optimization process, cycle times could be reduced to a (sub) second level and the total process, growth, and annealing would be significantly faster compared to the state- of- the- art passivation schemes applied presently.
